attachments.title: Widely Used Software Company May Be Entry Point for Huge U.S. Hacking
attachments.author_name: By Nicole Perlroth, David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
attachments.text: Russian hackers may have piggybacked on a tool developed by JetBrains, which is based in the Czech Republic, to gain access to federal government and private sector systems in the United States.

messages.text: Would something like this be possible in Julia if a bad actor could replace some part of a package the hack target is using? Let’s say the target is using package X, and it’s modified. The modification replaces some key part of Julia elsewhere, maybe compiler, maybe arithmetic, or something else. The stated functionality of X as such would have nothing to do with that key functionality, but would be perhaps a pretty printing or some other convenience package, or it could be a package with very few users.

attachments.title: Widely Used Software Company May Be Entry Point for Huge U.S. Hacking
attachments.author_name: By Nicole Perlroth, David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
attachments.text: Russian hackers may have piggybacked on a tool developed by JetBrains, which is based in the Czech Republic, to gain access to federal government and private sector systems in the United States.
attachments.fallback: The New York Times Widely Used Software Company May Be Entry Point for Huge U.S. Hacking

elements.text: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/01/06/us/politics/russia-cyber-hack.html

Would something like this be possible in Julia if a bad actor could replace some part of a package the hack target is using? Let’s say the target is using package X, and it’s modified. The modification replaces some key part of Julia elsewhere, maybe compiler, maybe arithmetic, or something else. The stated functionality of X as such would have nothing to do with that key functionality, but would be perhaps a pretty printing or some other convenience package, or it could be a package with very few users.

messages.text: Question: Is there a physical limit to how much a person can learn a day? Assume that an individual has 14 - 16 hours and they read all day long, taking breaks only for food and bathroom and for exercise, is there a point where the brain is just too fatigued to learn? Furthermore, for those involved with sleep research, how much sleep would a person need to consolidate new information?

elements.text: Question: Is there a physical limit to how much a person can learn a day? Assume that an individual has 14 - 16 hours and they read all day long, taking breaks only for food and bathroom and for exercise, is there a point where the brain is just too fatigued to learn? Furthermore, for those involved with sleep research, how much sleep would a person need to consolidate new information?

messages.text: This is just a question I have had for a while and was wondering if there has been any research done on this area! :thinking_face:

elements.text: This is just a question I have had for a while and was wondering if there has been any research done on this area!

messages.text:
Personally, I can only do about 3 hours of “deep thinking” a day where I really feel like the information is fresh and I can work with it in an active way.

After those 3 hours, the rest of the day I can do “rote” work - but rote work is special: the quality/level of rote work can be increased and improved over time by the active learning during the 3 hours.

So e.g. dealing with large amounts of complexity in information content I tend to try and consolidate into the time when I’m “fresh” and then other things which are about even/below _my level_ of rote work I try to leave for the rest of the day.

I believe these sorts of active/rote hours deal with fundamentally different “neural circuitry” (although this may be totally wrong). I’ve noticed that: even if I try to extend the 3 hours by ingesting caffeine (for example) - the quality of my active learning decreases substantially. It really feels like a sort of fatigue.

But I do tend to think of the brain as a muscle - you may be at the level where your rote work is something I could only attempt during the fresh, active learning periods of the day. Your brain may have been accustomed to those concepts / you don’t need to exert it to express understanding as much as I need to.

elements.text:
Personally, I can only do about 3 hours of “deep thinking” a day where I really feel like the information is fresh and I can work with it in an active way.

After those 3 hours, the rest of the day I can do “rote” work - but rote work is special: the quality/level of rote work can be increased and improved over time by the active learning during the 3 hours.

So e.g. dealing with large amounts of complexity in information content I tend to try and consolidate into the time when I’m “fresh” and then other things which are about even/below
my level

of rote work I try to leave for the rest of the day.

I believe these sorts of active/rote hours deal with fundamentally different “neural circuitry” (although this may be totally wrong). I’ve noticed that: even if I try to extend the 3 hours by ingesting caffeine (for example) - the quality of my active learning decreases substantially. It really feels like a sort of fatigue.

But I do tend to think of the brain as a muscle - you may be at the level where your rote work is something I could only attempt during the fresh, active learning periods of the day. Your brain may have been accustomed to those concepts / you don’t need to exert it to express understanding as much as I need to.

messages.text: I’ve also found that prolonged periods of rest will artificially increase the amount of active learning time which I can potentially spend - e.g. if I don’t think or program very hard for a week or longer, I can boost that amount of time for a few days - before it falls back to my observed patterns.

elements.text: I’ve also found that prolonged periods of rest will artificially increase the amount of active learning time which I can potentially spend - e.g. if I don’t think or program very hard for a week or longer, I can boost that amount of time for a few days - before it falls back to my observed patterns.

messages.text: Curious to hear what other people have found!

elements.text: Curious to hear what other people have found!

messages.text: I've never found my brain to be that predictable

elements.text: I've never found my brain to be that predictable

messages.text: I’m not enumerating the squirrel! moments throughout the day.

elements.text: I’m not enumerating the squirrel! moments throughout the day.

messages.text:
Also, my brain used to be more unpredictable. I actually worry that thinking and working in a routine like this kills creativity in some sense (but routine has a number of benefits). I don’t really have any proof of this - but I always feel like I’m my most creative after breaks.

Brains are weird AF.

elements.text:

Brains are weird AF.

messages.text: That reminds me of something I think about from time to time but haven't really researched - sudden genius symptom, where people just become proficient in a highly complex task overnight. There are examples here:<https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/brain-gain-a-person-can-instantly-blossom-into-a-savant-and-no-one-knows-why/|https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/brain-gain-a-person-can-instantly-blossom-into-a-savant-and-no-one-knows-why/>. No idea what to make of it but the possibility that this exists is mind boggling

attachments.title: Brain Gain: A Person Can Instantly Blossom into a Savant--and No One Knows Why
attachments.text: Some people suddenly become accomplished artists or musicians with no previous interest or training. Is it possible innate genius lies dormant within everyone?
attachments.fallback: Scientific American Blog Network: Brain Gain: A Person Can Instantly Blossom into a Savant--and No One Knows Why

elements.text: That reminds me of something I think about from time to time but haven't really researched - sudden genius symptom, where people just become proficient in a highly complex task overnight. There are examples here:
https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/observations/brain-gain-a-person-can-instantly-blossom-into-a-savant-and-no-one-knows-why/
. No idea what to make of it but the possibility that this exists is mind boggling

messages.text: I don't buy into this line that popular neuroscience sells about one of the principle features of sleep being "memory consolidation".

elements.text: I don't buy into this line that popular neuroscience sells about one of the principle features of sleep being "memory consolidation".

messages.text: To be honest I don't think I'm convinced of basically any of the big lines in behavioral neuroscience. I worked for several years in a reputed institution dedicated to learning and memory. I learned a bit there, but the biggest take-away I got from that job was lasting cognitive dissonance about how much money these people were operating with compared to how absolutely _blase_ they were about the reproducability of their results.

they were about the reproducability of their results.

messages.text: when I was studying for my qualifying exams in grad school, I had a big bibliography to get through.  I could do like two papers a day, and this was stuff in my area that I already had at least passing familiarity with.  That pace of two papers a day, each of which probably took an hour or two, for like a month or two left me totally drained

messages.text: Looking for mechanical keyboards option that are wireless, cheap ($60 - $80) and shippable to Canada.

elements.text: Looking for mechanical keyboards option that are wireless, cheap ($60 - $80) and shippable to Canada.

messages.text: I was looking at the Keychron K6 (<https://www.keychron.com/products/keychron-k6-wireless-mechanical-keyboard>) looks sooooo good, but shipping to canada adds another $24 on top which is fairly steep

attachments.service_name: Keychron | Wireless Mechanical Keyboards for Mac, Windows and Android
attachments.title: Keychron K6 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard
attachments.text: Keychron K6 Compact Wireless Mechanical Keyboard. 65% Layout. Wireless or Wired. Users can hot swap every switch in seconds with the hot-swappable version. Compatible with Mac, Windows, iOS, Android, Linux. Optical or Gateron Switches. Connect up to 3 devices. 15+ RGB Backlight
attachments.fallback: Keychron | Wireless Mechanical Keyboards for Mac, Windows and Android: Keychron K6 Wireless Mechanical Keyboard

messages.text: I don't care for RGB stuff, and I've never really mind wires... but I think I want wireless this time (bluetooth) since I only have usb c on laptop

messages.text: I just got to read about <https://koka-lang.github.io/koka/doc/index.html|Koka>, it has really interesting <https://koka-lang.github.io/koka/doc/book.html|semantics>. ¿What are your thoughts on this new language?

attachments.title: The Koka Programming Language
attachments.text: Provides an automatically expanding table-of-contents in a side-panel next to the main content. The TOC must be in a `SidePanel` block, while all the other content must be in a `MainPanel`.

messages.text: Hi there! Nothing important, but just to say I have played a bit with nightly builds of Julia and it is so much faster for testing my packages. Thanks to the dev team, you're doing awesome work :slightly_smiling_face:
